title: ISRO's Chandrayaan Mission
summary: How orbital mechanics, rocket propulsion, and gravity help India reach the Moon.
content:
Case Study: ISRO's Chandrayaan Mission

On 23 August 2023, Chandrayaan-3's Vikram lander touched down near the lunar south pole — making India the first country to do so. This remarkable achievement is pure applied physics.

Rocket Propulsion

Newton's Third Law: exhaust gases pushed backward propel the rocket forward. The GSLV rocket burns thousands of kilograms of propellant to build enough velocity to escape Earth's gravity.

Orbital Mechanics

After launch, ISRO scientists use small engine burns to gradually raise the orbit. Kepler's laws describe how planets and spacecraft move — a higher orbit means slower orbital speed.

Escape Velocity

Earth's escape velocity is ~11.2 km/s. Chandrayaan-3 was placed in a trans-lunar injection — an elliptical orbit that reaches the Moon's orbit. The Moon's gravity then captures the spacecraft.

Landing

The powered descent used retro-rockets to decelerate from ~1.68 km/s to near zero — a perfect application of the impulse-momentum theorem. Sensor data updated the onboard computer 100s of times per second!
